headline: No proof for Dr. Oz’s claim that Pa. GOP Senate rival Dave McCormick ‘paid for attacks’ on Trump
author: Tom Kertscher
sentences: Federal Election Commission records show that when Trump first ran for president, McCormick in 2015 gave $2,700 to the campaign of one of Trump’s competitors for the Republican nomination, former Florida Gov.
The major Republican candidates for an open U.S. Senate seat in Pennsylvania have touted their support of former President Donald Trump ahead of the state’s May 17 primary election.
An Associated Press news story published March 15, five days after Oz’s campaign posted its ad on YouTube, suggested that the ad’s claim alludes to McCormick’s support of Bush.

Featured Fact-check
"In 2015, McCormick held a fundraiser for Jeb Bush, once a contender for the 2016 GOP presidential nomination eventually won by Trump," the story said.
McCormick gave money to the campaign of one of Trump’s rivals for the 2016 Republican nomination for president, but that doesn’t amount to financing attacks on Trump.
Foreign Policy, which revealed the moves, said they appeared to be "the outgoing Trump administration’s parting shot at scions of the foreign-policy establishment."

"Oz's campaign pounced, saying in an ad, ‘Wall Street insider David McCormick paid for attacks on Donald Trump.’"
McCormick eventually came into Trump’s favor.
The other GOP candidates include conservative commentator Kathy Barnette, real estate developer Jeff Bartos and Carla Sands, Trump's ambassador to Denmark.
In November 2020, Trump removed McCormick and 10 other members of the board, including former Secretaries of State Henry Kissinger and Madeleine Albright.
And in November 2017, McCormick, a former Army officer, was named to the advisory Defense Policy Board by James Mattes, Trump’s defense secretary.
That includes physician and talk show host Dr. Mehmet Oz and Dave McCormick, the former chief executive of the Bridgewater Associates hedge fund.
The Pennsylvania race is for the seat held by Republican Pat Toomey, who was first elected in 2010 and who decided not to seek re-election.

An Oz TV ad painted McCormick as anti-Trump, declaring:
"Wall Street insider David McCormick paid for attacks on Donald Trump."
McCormick was a Treasury Department official in the administration of President George W. Bush, Jeb Bush’s brother.
When the narrator in the ad makes the attack on McCormick, a reference to "FEC Records" appears on the screen.
"I wasn't particularly involved with the Trump camp — I wasn't a Trump supporter," he said in March 2017.
But McCormick’s wife, Dina Powell McCormick, served as Trump’s deputy national security adviser.
The outcome could help determine which party controls the Senate, which is now split 50-50.
Oz’s campaign did not respond to our requests for information to back its claim.
The records indicate McCormick didn’t donate to Trump’s 2016 or 2020 campaigns.
The Democratic candidates include U.S. Rep. Conor Lamb and Lt. Gov.
The race is rated as a tossup and as "battleground Republican."
Without evidence for the claim, we rate the claim False.
Oz said McCormick "paid for attacks" on Trump.
Jeb Bush, and $5,000 to Bush’s leadership PAC.
We found no evidence of that.
